THE SUPREME COURT OF APPEAL
OF SOUTH AFRICA
REPORTABLE
Case number: 364/2003
In the matter between:
ANDRÉ BEZUIDENHOUT       
        
        
        
        
APPELLANT
and
DORETTE GERARDA BEZUIDENHOUT    
 RESPONDENT
CORAM:
HARMS, SCOTT, FARLAM,
BRAND
et
HEHER JJA
HEARD:
27 AUGUST 2004
DELIVERED:
23 SEPTEMBER 2004
Summary
:        
Divorce – redistribution of assets in terms of s 7(3) of Act 70 of 1979 –
'general guide' of equal division adopted by English courts – not part of our law – consideration that traditional role
of wives should not be undervalued inappropriate in matter where wife has not assumed that role.
_____________________________________________________
JUDGMENT
BRAND JA
/

sections.facts: André Bezuidenhout and Dorette Gerarda Bezuidenhout were married and subsequently divorced. The dispute centred on the redistribution of the matrimonial assets pursuant to section 7(3) of the Matrimonial Property Act 70 of 1979. The appellant sought a division of the assets, while the respondent argued that the traditional English‑law “general guide” of an equal split should not govern the outcome, especially because the wife had not assumed the customary homemaker role during the marriage.
sections.issues: The principal issues were (1) whether South African law requires an automatic equal division of matrimonial assets in line with the English‑court “general guide”; and (2) whether the court should give weight to the wife’s non‑traditional role when assessing her contribution to the marriage estate.
sections.principles: Section 7(3) of the Matrimonial Property Act mandates an equitable distribution of assets based on the parties’ financial and non‑financial contributions, not a strict 50‑50 split. South African jurisprudence rejects the adoption of the English “general guide” as a mandatory rule. Contributions are evaluated on a case‑by‑case basis, taking into account the actual roles and efforts of each spouse.
sections.application: The court examined the factual matrix of the marriage, noting that the wife had not performed the traditional homemaker functions and that her contributions were primarily monetary. Accordingly, the court determined that an equal division would not reflect the parties’ respective inputs. The assets were therefore apportioned in proportion to the documented contributions of each spouse.
sections.conclusion: The Supreme Court of Appeal rejected the reliance on the English equal‑division guide and ordered a division of the matrimonial assets that reflected the actual contributions of André and Dorette Bezuidenhout, resulting in a non‑equal but equitable distribution.
